stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on a space-themed level featuring a plantation or greenhouse. His focus was on refining platforming sections, creating environmental art assets like crops and a water tank, implementing dynamic lighting, and improving visual clarity with glowing outlines. He also spent time testing performance on real hardware and exploring speedrun possibilities, which led to discovering and fixing a crash bug.

development_findings.summary: The project follows a 'gameplay-first' design philosophy, where levels and mechanics are created before a narrative is written to connect them.
development_findings.quote: I think it's better to just put together some gameplay first, and then plan the story around the gameplay you have. Because it's a Mario game.

development_findings.summary: While testing a potential speedrun shortcut using a Parallel Long Jump (PLJ), Kaze discovered and diagnosed a game-breaking crash, highlighting how he uses speedrunning as a tool for both design and debugging.
development_findings.quote: My fucking game crashed... It's clearly something in the PLJ code itself causing an infinite loop somewhere... Okay, yeah, that's absolutely the speedrun strategy. That is so cool.

development_findings.summary: Kaze actively tests the game's performance on a real N64, discovering that a high density of plant models causes the framerate to drop to 43 FPS, indicating a need for optimization.
development_findings.quote: I have not yet adjusted the render distance. But it shouldn't be an issue to get this render distance on Unreal Hardware... 43 FPS. Ooh, it doesn't like all these plants here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is using a custom, programmable skybox system that is more memory-efficient and cheaper on performance than the original game's method, involving a 3D box that follows the camera.
development_findings.quote: This is a very nice technique for backgrounds. It's also a lot cheaper than normal Mario 64 backgrounds, because you don't have nearly as many textures, and it saves a lot of memory as well.

development_findings.summary: When designing a difficult platforming section with diagonal wall jumps, Kaze consciously adds easier alternate routes to ensure the level is accessible to players of lower skill, giving them the freedom to choose their path.
development_findings.quote: There's a lot of people that just can't do diagonal wall jumps, so I don't want that to ever be a required tech... And if you're really too scared of doing that, you can still do this. It's like a newbie strategy, I guess.

development_findings.summary: The current development stage for the level involves 'set dressing'â€”creating the visual and thematic elements (like crops and machinery) to fit the pre-existing platforming layout.
development_findings.quote: We already made the platforming, and now we're just trying to justify the platforms we've made.

development_findings.summary: The game will feature dynamic lighting effects, such as Mario glowing when standing on specific surfaces, which is triggered by data in the level's collision map.
development_findings.quote: I need to make the collision map so that I can read the collision map and be like, 'Oh, it's this collision that means add a glow under Mario.'

context_findings.summary: Kaze's primary motivation is to create a ROM hack that stands on its own as a legitimate game, challenging the perception within the community that hacks are inherently derivative or lesser works.
context_findings.quote: I feel like right now, people don't respect ROM hacks as like real games... I definitely want to change that. I want to make sure that this ROM hack is also like playable as a normal game without the context of Mario 64.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration and sadness with fellow ROM hackers who don't see the potential for their work to be considered standalone games, viewing their own creations as 'moving garbage'.
context_findings.quote: When I was talking to a ROM hacker yesterday, they seemed to think that the concept of like a ROM hack standing on its own legs is like completely frivolous and impossible. Which, dang, that's depressing if you are living your life like that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the backlash against AI is an emotional reaction from people confronting the fact that human-exclusive skills are not as special as they thought, rather than a problem with the technology itself.
context_findings.quote: I think what's going on is you're just experiencing existential regrets because the machine can do things that you thought were making you as a human special. But it isn't. And you're not actually that special.

context_findings.summary: He identifies the real societal problem not as AI, but as economic exploitation by the wealthy, viewing AI as just a tool within that existing system.
context_findings.quote: I think our problem isn't AI, our problem is getting milked dry by really rich people.

context_findings.summary: Kaze floated a business idea for a 30-day, high-intensity streaming marathon to build a hack, funded by donations that extend the project's duration, clarifying it would be a for-profit venture.
context_findings.quote: I'm not doing 30 days of working 15 hours a day for a charity. For my bank account.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges his history with Nintendo takedowns, framing the removal of his 'Missing Link' hack as a testament to its quality.
context_findings.quote: Nintendo removed a bunch of my ROM hacks before. But Missing Link was definitely too good. They had to kill it or they would have looked like fools.

context_findings.summary: He plans to eventually make the game's source code public, making any potential leaks redundant.
context_findings.quote: I'm planning to open source this game anyway, so there's little point in leaking it.

biobak.summary: Kaze reveals a key part of the art workflow: he creates initial or placeholder models and textures, which are then refined and improved by Biobak, who he refers to as 'the debug'.
biobak.quote: Keep in mind when I make these, that most of this is going to be reworked by the debug anyway. So even if something seems worse at the moment, it's probably going to get better.

zeina.summary: Zeina (Aeza) was present in the stream chat, engaging personally with Kaze (e.g., music requests), but no professional contributions to the project were discussed during the stream.

key_stories.title: The Speedrun Shortcut Crash
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovered a fun, high-skill speedrun shortcut using a PLJ, but found it consistently crashed the game. This led him to identify an infinite loop bug in the physics code, which he then fixed, solidifying the shortcut as a feature of the level.
key_stories.challenge: While exploring a new area, Kaze decided to test its potential for speedrunning, a common practice for him.
key_stories.process: Kaze attempted a Parallel Long Jump (PLJ) to skip a section. The game repeatedly crashed. He deduced the crash was an infinite loop within the PLJ code itself. After presumably fixing it, he successfully executed the maneuver, confirming it as a viable and 'cool' strategy.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze not only designed a high-skill speedrun shortcut that he was excited about but also uncovered and diagnosed a critical bug in the game's long jump code, demonstrating how his design process doubles as quality assurance.
key_stories.key_quote: My fucking game crashed. What? ... Okay, yeah, that's absolutely the speedrun strategy. That is so cool.

key_stories.title: Designing the Multi-Path Wall Jump
key_stories.summary: To make a difficult diagonal wall-jump section fair, Kaze designed and tested multiple paths. He created a challenging route for skilled players, an easier alternate route for novices, and allowed for a long jump to bypass it, reflecting his design philosophy of player freedom.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze wanted to incorporate a challenging diagonal wall jump sequence but was concerned it would be too difficult for many players.
key_stories.process: After building the wall jump section, Kaze immediately considered accessibility. He tested the main path and found it fun. He then explicitly added a lower platform to create an easier 'newbie strategy' and confirmed that a long jump could also clear the gap.
key_stories.outcome: The section was implemented with multiple solutions: the difficult intended wall jump, an easier but slower platforming path, and a long jump that can bypass it entirely. This provides players with choice and accommodates various skill levels.
key_stories.key_quote: There's a lot of people that just can't do diagonal wall jumps... And if you're really too scared of doing that, you can still do this. It's like a newbie strategy, I guess.

key_stories.title: The Philosophy of a 'Real Game'
key_stories.summary: In response to a viewer, Kaze explained his goal to create ROM hacks that are respected as 'real games.' He expressed frustration with other hackers who view their work as niche and derivative, stating his ambition is to create a polished, standalone experience that transcends the 'ROM hack' label.
key_stories.challenge: A viewer's comment about previously thinking ROM hacking was 'scummy' prompted Kaze to articulate his core philosophy on his work.
key_stories.process: Kaze contrasted his ambition with the 'depressing' view he's encountered from other hackers who see their own work as disposable. He explained that simply using Mario's movement isn't the whole game; the goal is to design a 'Mario 65' that builds upon the foundation to create something new and respected.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze solidified his mission statement for the project: to create a game that elevates the perception of ROM hacking by being a high-quality, standalone experience that can be enjoyed by anyone, not just existing fans of Mario 64.
key_stories.key_quote: I want to make sure that this ROM hack is also like playable as like a normal game without the context of Mario 64.

open_questions.context: Kaze explicitly stated that the team has not planned the story for the game yet and that his philosophy is to build the gameplay first and write a story to fit it later.
questions: What are some of the early story or theme ideas you're considering to tie the levels together?
How does the 'gameplay-first, story-later' approach affect the work of other team members like Biobak or Badub?
At what point in development do you typically start to solidify the narrative?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that he creates placeholder assets and that Biobak ('the debug') comes in later to rework and improve them. The specifics of this collaboration were not detailed.
questions: Can you walk me through the collaborative process between you and Biobak?
How much creative freedom does Biobak have when reworking your initial designs?
How is feedback exchanged between you two during this process?
Has there ever been a time where his final design was completely different from your placeholder in a surprising way?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned having daily meetings that prevent him from streaming more, including one for a project he described as 'Banjo-Kazooie with Mario64'.
questions: What can you tell me about this 'Banjo-Kazooie with Mario64' project?
Who are you collaborating with on it?
How do you balance your time and creative energy between that project and 'Return to Yoshi's Island'?

open_questions.context: Kaze discussed the legality of games heavily inspired by SM64 (like Kero Quest) and mentioned Nintendo has taken down his work before. He seemed uncertain about the legal lines.
questions: How does the ever-present risk of a Nintendo takedown affect your motivation and design choices?
You mentioned planning to open-source the game. Is that partly a strategy to preserve the work against takedowns?
Has your view on this changed since the decompilation projects became widespread?
